results.title: What's the name of that place you come from nan?
results.creator_credit: Rita Hinekauia Morrison and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: Rita comes from a mixed cultural background but her strongest connection is with the Maori side of her family. She shares her memories and family history in this digital story so that her Maori heritage can be preserved through future generations.
results.title_for_label: What’s the name of that place you come from nan?

results.title: How much you mean to me nan
results.creator_credit: Chris Mansfield and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: She is always there when things get rough, she is the backbone of our mob, she is my nan…and I will love her always. A dedication by Chris to his nan.

results.title: ASHE: the way of life
results.creator_credit: Colin Colger and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: After the death of his mother and losing his way to a life of crime, Colin, a sports loving Shepparton boy, was offered a new beginning - a lifeline - through ASHE (Academy of Health Sports and Education).

results.title: The Four musketeers

results.title: Life in horror
results.brief_description: Duy ever since a child has had an obsession with horror movies - they are his life and he knows them all. He has rules to avoid real life horror situations and his philosophy on life - live it to the max!

results.title: The Passing
results.creator_credit: Bill Viola, Artists' Television Workshop at WXXI/TV, Rochester and TV Lab at WNET/Thirteen
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, black and white and audio
results.brief_description:
Engaged in projects all over the world, Bill Viola has become one of the most celebrated artists working with the moving image. His installations are admired for the lightness with which they address weighty themes: birth, death, the nature of time and impermanence, the mania of individuality contending with the benefits and responsibilities of the human, communal condition. Time and again, Viola organises his installations around dramatic ‘moments of distinction’, like the breath coming in and out of a body distinguishing vitality from mortality, or the blinking eye distinguishing the energy in light from the absence that
is darkness.

In The Passing viewers watch a man - the artist - sleep, and they also witness visions that emerge from his unconscious. As they are bathed in the glow of the dreamer’s imaginary, as they sway to the pulsing of the engulfing soundtrack and feel the dimensions of their own body altering in response to the shifts of scale and variations of weightlessness, they sense a slow but profound shift in their consciousness.

Time passes in an unaccustomed manner, basic emotions like fear and attraction seem to offer themselves for fresh consideration. There is no pre-defined, ‘right’ duration for an encounter with this work. Visitors tend to stay for as long as it takes to feel an alteration; this can be ten seconds, or it can be hours. The Passing might have a beginning, middle and end mapped into its 52-minute linear duration, but the installation is best regarded as an endless loop that circulates like an enormous conceptual mantra, always available for engagement and orientation. No matter where in the timeline a viewer first submerges into The Passing, they will almost instantly find themselves attuned to rhythms and
glimmers that can guide them along their own passage through memory and self-examination to enlightenment.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bill Viola, Artists’ Television Workshop at WXXI/TV, Rochester and TV Lab at WNET/Thirteen

results.title: We shall remember them
results.creator_credit: John Thompson, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: John Thompson remembers the generations of soldiers that have passed through the Australian Light Horse Memorial Park in Seymour. While honouring their memory, he also welcomes the restoration of the park to create a place of beauty for all future Australians.

results.title: Vocational indecision
results.creator_credit: Leanne Beattie, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Leanne Beattie takes us down the long path to finding her ideal career. It is not always something that comes to you during your school years, and maybe not for a long time after that, but sometimes, when you just focus on what you enjoy, eventually you find it.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Leanne Beattie, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: An Album of sunny memories: for Delcie
results.creator_credit: Dale Williamson, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Dale Williamson provides rich detail of the life of her mother Delcie. From Victory Girl in her beloved Cygnet in Tasmania to wife and mother of four children, Delcie has led a life of simple joys and familial love.
